material.mattext: Will Hunting pushes away everyone who gets close - Skylar, his friends, and initially Sean. According to attachment theory and emotion regulation research (Gross, 2015), which regulatory strategy does this pattern represent?
Cognitive reappraisal of relationship value
Situation selection that avoids emotional contexts entirely
Expressive suppression of positive emotions
Attentional deployment toward threat cues

Correct!

Will's pattern is consistent with situation selection - he prevents emotionally demanding situations from occurring in the first place. By pushing people away before they get close, he avoids the situation of being vulnerable. This is an antecedent-focused strategy in Gross's model - it operates before the emotional response is fully generated. Will doesn't just suppress emotions that arise; he prevents the situations that would generate them.

The correct answer is B.

By pushing people away before they get close, he avoids the situation of being vulnerable. This is an antecedent-focused strategy in Gross's model - it operates before the emotional response is fully generated. Will doesn't just suppress emotions that arise; he prevents the situations that would generate them.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Reappraisal would involve changing how he thinks about relationships, not avoiding them entirely.
  • C: Suppression occurs AFTER emotions arise. Will prevents the relationship situations that would generate emotions.
  • D: Will doesn't redirect attention within situations; he eliminates the situations entirely.

Will's foster father burned him with cigarettes, yet Will questions whether he "deserved" the abuse. According to Boudry and Braeckman (2012), why might abuse victims develop self-blaming beliefs despite evidence to the contrary?
Children lack cognitive capacity to assign blame appropriately
Self-blame provides an illusion of control and predictability
Self-validating belief systems develop where self-blame is more psychologically tolerable than acknowledging complete powerlessness
Abusers explicitly teach victims to accept blame

Correct!

Boudry & Braeckman's framework applies to any self-validating belief. Self-blame for abuse is "self-validating" because it serves psychological functions: if I caused the abuse, then I have some control (I could have prevented it by being "better"). Acknowledging complete powerlessness is more terrifying than accepting undeserved blame. The belief system validates itself by providing an explanatory framework, even if that framework is painful.

The correct answer is C.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Will is an adult still maintaining these beliefs. Cognitive capacity isn't the issue.
  • B: This is partially correct but doesn't capture the SELF-VALIDATING aspect - how the belief resists disconfirmation.
  • D: While abusers may do this, the question is about why victims MAINTAIN the belief. The self-validating nature explains persistence.
Sean shares his own pain with Will (his wife's death, his imperfections). According to research on therapeutic relationships, why does this self-disclosure succeed where previous therapists failed?
Professional boundaries should always be violated in effective therapy
Shared suffering creates automatic rapport
Will needed to feel superior to his therapist
The disclosure models emotional differentiation - acknowledging multiple simultaneous feelings - and demonstrates that vulnerability does not equal weakness

Correct!

Sean's disclosure serves multiple functions: it MODELS differentiation (he can feel grief AND acceptance, love AND loss simultaneously) and demonstrates that vulnerability doesn't destroy you (Sean is wounded but functional). Will has learned that showing pain means being weak and exploited. Sean's example contradicts this by showing differentiated emotional experience combined with strength. This is more instructive than any cognitive technique.

The correct answer is D.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Too extreme. The self-disclosure is JUDICIOUS and therapeutic, not a general endorsement of boundary violation.
  • B: Superficial. Shared suffering might create connection, but it's the MODELING of differentiation that creates change.
  • C: Contradicts what happens. Will doesn't feel superior to Sean; he respects him.

Lambeau wants Will to use his mathematical genius for prestigious careers. Will resists, eventually choosing to pursue Skylar to California. According to McKnight et al. (2025), what does this choice suggest about the relationship between purpose and happiness?
Will sacrifices purpose for happiness
Intellectual purpose is less valid than relational purpose
Happiness (connection with Skylar) may be facilitating his emerging sense of purpose rather than competing with it
Will's choice demonstrates purpose avoidance

Correct!

McKnight et al. (2025) found that happiness predicts subsequent purpose, not vice versa. Will's positive emotional experiences with Skylar and Sean may be creating the conditions for purpose to develop. He's not choosing happiness OVER purpose; he's experiencing happiness that may ENABLE purpose. Following Skylar isn't abandoning purpose - it's pursuing the emotional experiences that facilitate purpose development.

The correct answer is C.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Assumes purpose and happiness are in competition. The research suggests happiness facilitates purpose.
  • B: The framework doesn't rank purpose types. Will may integrate intellectual purpose later.
  • D: Will isn't avoiding purpose; he's pursuing emotional experiences that may enable it.

Will can solve complex mathematical proofs but cannot solve his own psychological problems. This dissociation illustrates which limitation in the "smart people believe weird things" phenomenon (Shermer, 2002)?
Mathematical intelligence differs from emotional intelligence
Intellectual sophistication enables rationalization of emotional avoidance, making smart people more effective at constructing defenses
Genius exempts people from normal psychological processes
Will's problems are too complex for anyone to solve

Correct!

Shermer's insight is that intelligence provides better tools for rationalization, not better outcomes. Will's genius allows him to construct sophisticated justifications for his emotional avoidance. When challenged, he can argue circles around therapists. His intelligence doesn't help him overcome his defenses - it strengthens them by providing better defensive arguments. Smart people aren't protected from irrationality; they're better at defending it.

The correct answer is B.

  • A: While this distinction exists, it doesn't capture Shermer's point about rationalization.
  • C: The opposite - Will is fully subject to psychological processes. His genius doesn't protect him.
  • D: Will's problems are solvable, as the film demonstrates. Complexity isn't the issue.
